choices.text: Cell swelling, pyknosis, swelling of endoplasmic reticulum.
Cell swelling, membrane blebs, membrane damage.
Cells swelling, membrane blebs, hydropic change.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented to emergency with chest pain, radiating to the left arm for last 15 minutes. Blood examination shows normal levels troponin and creatinine Kinase enzymes. The doctors at the emergency room successfully save the patient with treatment. If it would have been possible to examine microscopic sections during the episode which of the following would have been most likely cellular change?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

cell swelling, membrane blebs and hydropic change. This patient is having pain which lasted 15 minutes and no elevated enzymes meaning reversible injury. Thus answer C.

questions.text: In an experimental disease in mice, it was found that there was loss of individual cells, microscopy showing karyorrhexis and cellular fragmentation with an overall intact tissue architecture. Which of the following disease it is most likely to have a similar description?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Single cell death + karyorrhexis  Apoptosis. Acute viral hepatitis causes Councilman bodies which are apoptotic bodies.

questions.text: In response to increase in work load the cells can undergo increase in cellular organelle, cell size and function this is termed as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

increased cell size is hypertrophy.

choices.text: Loss of nuclei of myocytes with retained cellular outlines.
Cell shrinkage, condensed cytoplasm and pyknotic nucleus.

questions.text: At autopsy of a 92-year-old man the pathologist grossly finds that the heart is small in size. Microscopic examination of the heart will show.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•    Lipofuscin (brown coloured pigment)  seen in brown atrophy.

•    In tissue sections it appears as a yellow brown, finely granular cytoplasmic, often perinuclear, pigment.

•    Cells undergo slow, regressive changes particularly prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman was diagnosed of Diffuse large B cell lymphoma involving lymph nodes in the para-aortic region. She was treated with a chemotherapeutic regimen (CHOP), Over the next 2 months, the lymphoma decreases in size, as documented on abdominal CT scans. By which of the following mechanisms has her neoplasm primarily responded to therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Apoptosis, Chemotherapy induced death is by apoptosis.

questions.text: Earliest features of acute inflammation is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vasoconstriction is earliest feature of acute inflammation which is transient and plays no role in inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following arachidonic acid metabolites inhibits chemotaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

LX A4.

questions.text: A 45-year male presents with weight loss and loss of appetite and low-grade fever. Which of the following cells & mediator explains the clinical manifestation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient is low-grade fever, weight loss and loss of appetite are features of chronic inflammation, the principal cell of chronic inflammation is macrophage which secrets TNF which leads to suppression of appetite centre and Thermoregulator in the hypothalamus leading to these manifestations.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, diabetic underwent excision of lipoma in the neck. 4 months later a scar is seen at the site of surgery, which is limited to the wound margins. Scar Biopsy shows parallel arranged collagen, which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Collagen is arranged parallelly which is suggestive off a hypertrophic scar, which will have type 3 collagen more than type one due to delayed or defective remodelling of the wound. Keloid will have type one collage and predominant and there will be haphazard arrangement of collagen.

questions.text: Patient with Crohn disease was started on infliximab, which of the complications can happen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reactivation of tuberculosis. Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody to TNF alpha which is an important mediator of chronic inflammation required to fight off tuberculosis, antagonising TNF alpha leads to decreased immunity against tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 35-year lady was about to be started on penicillin. 2 days after starting therapy she develops dark colour urine, urine examination confirms presence of haemoglobin and no RBC or cast or seen. And indirect Coombs test turns out to be positive. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for her manifestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction. The patient has developed haemoglobinuria [suggests intravascular hemolysis] in addition indirect Coombs test is positive that makes a diagnosis of drug induced autoimmune hemolytic anemia which are type 2 hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Mode of inheritance of major histocompatibility complex is.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Major histocompatibility complex [MHC] is Co dominant in inheritance and is located on chromosome 6P [Autosome]

questions.text: Site and type of dialysis associated amyloidosis is.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dialysis associated amyloidosis is amyloid beta 2 microglobulin which usually gets deposited in joints and on tendon.

questions.text: Diagnosis based on the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The image given is spleen [red organ with hilum] with multiple white Sago like granules seen in amyloidosis. This appearance is called sago spleen which is due to amyloid deposition in the white pulp.

questions.text: A child suffering from Alport syndrome is on wait list for renal transplant. During this waiting period he has received multiple blood transfusion and dialysis, final he gets a 4/6 matched donor. During transplantation surgeon observes that the graft has turned red and within few minutes it turns pale. The surgeon had to remove the graft which of the following would have led to such reaction in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The child has developed hyperacute rejection which is due to preformed anti HLA antibodies in the patient important risk factor for production of anti HLA antibodies are blood transfusion [non leukodepleted] and multiple pregnancy.

questions.text: True about telomerase
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 T telomerase is an RNA dependent DNA polymerase which adds TTAGGG repeats to the ends of the telomere after every cell division thus decreasing the shortening of the chromosome.

questions.text:
False about noncoding DNA

(1)    Do not produce RNA.

(2)    No protein synthesis

(3)    Function is not known.

(4)    Promoters and enhancers

(5)    Regulate DNA
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which disease is likely to follow the inheritance pattern shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Christmas disease. The given pedigree shows skipping of generation suggesting recessive, and only males are affected that makes It X linked recessive. Options A is AD>AR, B is AR.

choices.text: Can detect gene deletions but not point mutation.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about karyotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

karyotype cannot detect any mutation.

questions.text: If three base pairs are inserted in a gene, this leads to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

insertion of three or multiples of three leads to increase in no of amino acids keeping rest of the reading frame preserved thus called in frame mutation. Insertion of base pairs not in multiples of three leads to frame shift (aka out frame mutation)

questions.text: A pathologist has done FNAC of a thyroid tumor, he sees the cells are arranged in microfollicular pattern, with increased NC ration no colloid. He is unable to make a diagnosis of malignancy because he is unable to see which of the following features?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D)

invasion. Difference between benign vs malignant epithelial tumor (in this case follicular neoplasm of thyroid because of the cells are arranged in a microfollicular pattern) is invasion. In follicular we see for capsular or vascular invasion if not seen then it is called benign. On FNAC you can’t see any invasion as tissue architecture is not preserved.

choices.text: Loss of function of WT1 leads to neoplasm.
Gain of function of WT2 leads to neoplasm.
Loss of function of Bcl-2 leads to neoplasm.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about tumorogenesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gain of function of BCL-2 causes cancer as BCl-2 is antiapoptotic gene.

questions.text: A patient presents with weight loss and anemia. Blood examination Hb 6g/dL, MCH 78, MCV 98, retic count 0.5%. which of the following investigation would reveal a malignant condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient has reticulocytopenia (RC 0.5%) suggesting aplastic anemia, pure red cell aplasia is a paraneoplastic manifestation of thymoma which presents as a mediastinal mass.

questions.text: A patient presents with hematuria and weight loss. Imaging shows mass in kidney not invading capsule or the vessels, no lymph nodes were seen. Histological examination shows the tumor cells with clear cytoplasm and nuclear pleomorphism and frequent mitosis. Which of the following is true about this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

there is no invasion into capsule, vessel and no lymph node suggests the tumor is limited to the organ thus stage is low. Histology shows pleomorphism and mitosis which are suggestive of a high grade.

questions.text:
True about Warburg effect

(1)    Decreased ATP synthesis.

(2)    Anaerobic glycolysis

(3)    Seen during embryogenesis.

(4)    Seen in tumors.

(5)    Increased glucose consumption.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Warburg effect is shift of metabolism of glucose from oxidative phosphorylation to aerobic glycolysis not anaerobic.
